# Git Intro
![](https://www.nobledesktop.com/image/blog/git-branches-merge.png)
What is Git and why we use it ?

How can we download it and how we will work on it ?

In this blog we will have answers to these questions briefly, we will get basic knowldge of Git.

![](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

## 1. What is Git ?

Git is the most commonly used [Distributed Version Control
 system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_version_control). Git tracks the changes you make to files, so you have a record of what has been done, and you can revert to specific versions should you ever need to. Git also makes collaboration easier, allowing changes by multiple people to all be merged into one source. 

So regardless of whether you write code that only you will see, or work as part of a team, Git will be useful for you.
 
## 2. Download Git for windows users

You can download Git by visiting this link and following the posted directions:

[http://git-scm.com/download/win](http://git-scm.com/download/win)

GitHub

Install Git as part of the GitHub for Windows install.

[http://windows.github.com](http://windows.github.com)

## 3. Stage & Commit Files

Think of Git as keeping a list of changes to files. So how do we tell Git to record our changes? Each recorded change to a file or set of files is called a **commit**.

``` 
git commit -m "type what you changed "
```

**Before we make a commit**, we must tell Git what files we want to commit. This is called staging and uses the **add command**.

``` 
git add .
```
 Why must we do this? Why can’t we just commit the file directly? Let’s say you’re working on a two files, but only one of them is ready to commit. You don’t want to be forced to commit both files, just the one that’s ready. That’s where Git’s add command comes in. We add files to a staging area, and then we commit the files that have been staged.

## 4. Remote Repositories (on GitHub)

Storing a copy of your Git repo with an online host (such as GitHub or Bitbucket) gives you a centrally located place where you can upload your changes and download changes from others, letting you collaborate more easily with other developers. After you have a remote repository set up, you upload (push) your files

``` 
git push origin main 
```
 and revision history to it. After someone else makes changes to a remote repo, you can download (pull) 
 ```
 git pull origin main
 ```

 their changes into your local repo.

![](https://www.nobledesktop.com/image/blog/git-distributed-workflow-diagram.png)
